title: Netflix's Shift from Interactive Shows to Generative AI for Games
description: In this episode, we dive into Netflix's decision to end its interactive content experiment and focus on generative AI in gaming. We'll explore what this pivot means for Netflix and the future of streaming entertainment.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we’re looking at Netflix’s latest pivot away from interactive shows towards generative AI in gaming. It’s an intriguing move, and as reported by Gizmodo in their article 'Netflix Finally Gives Up on Interactive Shows, Pivots to GenAI for Games,' it marks yet another attempt by Netflix to expand beyond traditional streaming. Let's dive into the details and explore what this means for the platform—and for us as viewers and gamers.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Netflix initially launched its interactive content back in 2017, experimenting with a 'choose-your-own-adventure' format in a variety of shows and movies. These included some creative, although not heavily interactive, titles, like the *Headspace Guide to Meditation*, which combined wellness with a personalized meditation experience, and a children’s *Carmen Sandiego* show that let young viewers guide the character’s journey.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: While Netflix had high hopes for these shows, the reality was that the format didn’t quite catch on as widely as anticipated. In fact, only 24 interactive titles were ever made, according to Gizmodo. And as we can see from Netflix's recent actions, most of these shows will be delisted from the platform, leaving only a few of the more popular ones, like *Black Mirror: Bandersnatch*, *Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt: Kimmy vs. the Reverend*, *Ranveer vs. Wild with Bear Grylls*, and *You vs. Wild*.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: There are likely several reasons behind Netflix’s decision to move away from interactive content. For one, low popularity could be a factor. Additionally, licensing costs for shows based on external IPs, like *Boss Baby*, are not cheap. In the streaming world, companies have to pay yearly residuals to keep licensed titles, and by cutting these interactive shows, Netflix might be aiming to reduce these costs.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But the story doesn’t end there. Rather than abandoning innovation entirely, Netflix is now looking to generative AI to carve out its niche in gaming. The company has already been experimenting with games available on mobile, but this shift marks a new level of ambition. Netflix's head of gaming, Mike Vertu, has even taken on the title of 'VP of GenAI for Games.' He recently expressed his enthusiasm about this pivot on LinkedIn, saying he hasn’t felt this excited since the '90s, when new game releases brought groundbreaking experiences every few months.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The idea of generative AI in gaming is captivating. Netflix seems to be inspired by platforms like Roblox, where users can already generate 3D objects and scenes with simple AI prompts. Imagine a Netflix gaming experience where users can craft entire game worlds through a few commands or customize gameplay elements on the fly. It’s a new frontier that could attract creative and gaming audiences alike.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That said, this approach raises some questions. Can AI-generated games compete with traditional games crafted by skilled artists and writers? Creative vision still plays a huge role in gaming, and while AI can assist in generating assets or setting up environments, a game still needs that 'spark'—a story, a compelling experience that keeps people engaged. Will Netflix’s GenAI for games deliver that spark? Only time will tell.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: In any case, Netflix’s commitment to generative AI in gaming signals a fascinating shift, not just for the company but for the entertainment industry as a whole. It’s clear Netflix views the gaming space—and perhaps even social media—as competitors for audience attention. Co-founder Reed Hastings has commented before that gaming and social platforms are Netflix’s biggest competition. This move aligns with that perspective, aiming to capture engagement on multiple fronts.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what does the future hold? Don’t expect AAA blockbuster games from Netflix just yet. But with generative AI, Netflix might just find a way to bring interactive entertainment to audiences in a whole new form, one that sits at the intersection of streaming, gaming, and AI-driven creativity.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That’s it for today’s episode of 'Life is Artificial.' As always, I’d love to hear your thoughts. Do you think AI-generated games are the future of entertainment, or is this just another experiment? Check out the Gizmodo article for more on this story and stay tuned for more explorations into the world of artificial intelligence and technology. Until next time, keep imagining the possibilities.
